Award.AwardTitle: Imaging Spectroscopy of Coherent Radio Bursts on the Sun: a New Probe of Magnetic Energy Release
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will solely support a promising graduate student and form the basis of his Ph.D. thesis at the University of Virginia. The senior proposers will supervise this student in his study of coherent radio bursts as a diagnostic of magnetic energy release in solar flares. Under their guidance, the student will utilize state-of-the-art radio instrumentation to make fundamentally new observations of coherent bursts from flares, in the form of dynamic broadband imaging spectroscopy at decimeter wavelengths. These observations will allow the locations of flare magnetic energy release to be pinpointed, and the temporal and spatial evolution of these locations to be tracked. Depending on the particular type of radio burst, such observations can place constraints on the magnetic field and plasma density in and around the energy release sites of solar flares.

The new technique of broadband imaging spectroscopy at radio wavelengths promises to be transformative in solar physics. The proposers will exploit the newly upgraded instrumentation at the Expanded Very Large Array (EVLA, a facility of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, or NRAO), as well as the Frequency Agile Solar Radiotelescope (FASR) Subsystem test bed array and the Owens Valley Solar Array, two university instruments operated by the New Jersey Institute of Technology at the Owens Valley Radio Observatory in California.

This project will directly support the education and training of a promising PhD student and will contribute to the successful commissioning of the EVLA radiotelescope. EVLA is an extraordinary and powerful new instrument that will dramatically enhance existing research infrastructure and transform our capabilities for radio observations of the Sun. EVLA will also support a broad user community and make possible scientific studies that will have direct impact on our understanding of space weather phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research developed new techniques at radio wavelengths to study energetic phenomena on the Sun, phenomena that can drive so-called space weather, whcih can have a profound impact on the Earth and near-Earth environment. Specifically, a new generation of radio telescopes is under development that allows scientists to exploit dynamic imaging spectroscopy. That is, images of the Sun can be made at radio wavelengths at many frequencies simultaneously, over a broad range of frequencies, many times every second. As a concrete example, the recently upgraded Very Large Array, a facility of the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, can now make an image of the Sun in each of 1000 frequency channels distributed from 1-2 GHz (wavelengths of 15-30 cm) every 50 milliseconds. Since both the right- and left-hand senses of circularly polarized radiation are measured, that amounts to a total of 40,000 snapshot images of the Sun every second!

Imaging spectroscopy opens the possibility of exploiting new radio diagnostics to probe physical processes in the Sun's atmosphere. This research program was composed of two parts: 1) to develop the observational hardware and techniques to exploit imaging spectroscopy at radio wavelengths; 2) to perform pathfinding science using the technique, with a focus on energetic phenomena on the Sun: flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs).

Why is radio imaging as a function of time and frequency required? The mechanisms that produce radio waves in the Sun's atmosphere have distinctive signatures as a function of time and frequency. For example, an electron beam can be produced by magnetic energy release in a jet, flare, or CME. The beam excites plasma waves at a frequency that is proportional to the square root of the plasma denstiy. As the beam propagates, the radio frequency changes as the density changes along the beam trajectory. For a beam propagating from low in the corona to high in the corona, the frequency of the radio emission decreases with time because the coronal density decreases with height. In contrast, for a beam propagaring toward lower heights, the radio frequency increases with time. Hence, using dynamic imaging spectroscopy, we can track the origin and trajectory of electron beams that result from magnetic energy release.

A multitude of other mechanisms produce radio waves from the Sun. These depend on the plasma density, the magnetic field, and the energy distribution of the emitting electrons. All of these can be used to learn about the underlying phenomena. As another example, we used the VLA to observe a flare and fast CME in March 2012. It was also observed by NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory (SDO), a mission that images the Sun in the Extreme Ultraviolet using filters that are sensitive to plasma at different temperatures. The SDO data were used to place new constraints on the formation, evolution, and eruption of a magnetic flux rope and the associated CME. The radio data were used to observe radio bursts assocated with energy release in the current sheet behind the CME launched with the magnetic flux rope.

The future of dynamic imaging spectroscopy is extremely processing. The initial development supported by this research grant allowed us to train a graduate student, develop the necessary technical capabilities, and to apply the new capability to demonstrator science. Observing programs with the VLA are continuing, and the techniques we're learning are being used to inform other efforts; e.g., the implementation of solar observing on ALMA and imaging spectroscopy on the Expanded Owens Valley Solar Array. Ultimately, these techniques need to be fully exploited using a next generation radioheliograph - that is, a radio telescope dedicated to solar and space weather observations.
